misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that s.next() will capture a full name (as a single entity) even if it contains spaces, such as 'Alice Smith'.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not distinguish between a token (delimited by any whitespace) and a line (delimited by a newline character) in the Scanner's notional machine. s.next() stops at the first space, meaning names containing spaces will be split across multiple array indices, resulting in shifted data and subsequent InputMismatchExceptions when the program attempts to read strings as integers.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the input stream is partitioned by the program's prompts, assuming that the notional machine will wait for all names to be finished before looking for scores.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student views the input buffer as tied to the prompt context rather than as a single, linear stream of tokens. If a user provides input in a natural paired format (e.g., 'Alice 85 Bob 92'), the student's separate loops for names and scores will consume the tokens in a strictly sequential manner, resulting in the scores being read into the names array and causing an InputMismatchException when the second loop starts.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Scanner.next() will read a full name (e.g., 'Alice Smith') as a single entry in the names array, regardless of whether it contains spaces.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, the Scanner.next() method is delimited by any whitespace. If a student name contains a space, the first part is stored in the names array, and the second part is left in the buffer, leading to an InputMismatchException when the program later attempts to read a score as an integer.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the logic used to retrieve the result (using the index n-1) is safe for all possible values of N provided by the user.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student's mental model fails to account for the edge case where N is 0. While the loops for input and sorting will simply not execute, the final output line attempts to access index -1 of the arrays.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the input stream is strictly divided into two distinct blocks (all names then all scores), and that the computer can distinguish between them based on which loop is currently running.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student assumes the user will perfectly follow the 'all names then all scores' sequence. If a user provides data in pairs (Name1, Score1, Name2, Score2), the student's mental model doesn't recognize that the 'names' loop will greedily consume the first N tokens from the stream, regardless of whether they are names or scores.
